awd_abstract_narration:
Drexel University's College of Computing and Informatics will establish the CyberCorps Mentoring and Scholarship Program (CMSP) to recruit, train, and mentor 17 CMSP Scholars to transition into cybersecurity positions within federal, state, local, or tribal government organizations. The project will develop a CyberCorps Scholarship for Service (SFS) initiative that can contribute to improving cybersecurity by increasing the number and diversity of undergraduate students who complete cybersecurity degrees and then take positions within government agencies. The goal is for the CMSP to strengthen national cybersecurity by enhancing both the recruitment and retention of a diverse cybersecurity workforce.

A core focus of Drexel's CMSP is the successful recruitment, retention, and support of students who are women, underrepresented minorities, and veterans. The project addresses these groups through multiple forms of mentoring, guided by an approach to student development called Validation Theory. Validation Theory aims to provide a systematic understanding of the role of validation in the transition, persistence, and success of underrepresented college students. Components of the CMSP include faculty-student mentoring, monthly cohort meetings, extracurricular workshops, and other activities designed to validate students. These activities are particularly useful for recruiting and retaining women, underrepresented minorities, and veterans. Scholars will also be required to engage in cooperative education experiences (co-ops) that interleave classroom learning and real-world professional experience. The project will also provide further empirical support for Validation Theory's strengths and weaknesses as a theoretical framework. Existing instruments to understand the effects of Validation Theory will be extended for the CMSP program. A new quantitative instrument will also be developed to assess student perspectives of validation in and outside of classrooms. These products will be shared with the cybersecurity education community to support knowledge building in the areas of student recruiting, mentoring, and job placement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Drexel University’s CyberCorps Mentoring and Scholarship Program (CMSP) was developed to support students in cybersecurity fields and prepare them for critical roles in government service. Through a combination of classroom learning and hands-on cooperative education (co-ops), the program offers Drexel’s Computing and Security Technology (CST) and Computer Science (CS) majors an opportunity to gain 18 months of real-world work experience—significantly more than the national average for undergraduates. Students in the CMSP program complete these co-ops with organizations such as the National Security Agency (NSA), Department of Homeland Security (DHS), and Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA), ensuring that they graduate with practical skills and networks in government cybersecurity.

A core goal of CMSP has been to recruit, retain, and support women, underrepresented minorities, and veterans in cybersecurity. In fact, CMSP exceeded its diversity goals: among 18 participants, 61% were women, with additional representation from Black, Latino, and Asian communities, as well as a military veteran. This strong focus on inclusivity was achieved through proactive outreach and mentoring that ensured participants felt validated, supported, and empowered to succeed. CMSP’s approach was based on Validation Theory, which emphasizes the importance of validation for students from underrepresented groups in higher education. By applying this theory, CMSP has provided students with a sense of belonging and support, helping them navigate both academic and professional challenges.

The program’s success is evident in the outcomes of its graduates. All 18 CMSP students graduated on time, and nearly all have moved into full-time roles within government agencies, often receiving multiple job offers before graduation. The SFS (Scholarship for Service) Job Fair and USAjobs.gov played a significant role in connecting students to job opportunities in public service. By the end of the program, students were employed in agencies like the National Security Agency (NSA), Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA), and the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), where they will contribute to national security and public welfare.

Professional development was a significant theme across student experiences. Through personalized mentorship, students received guidance on interview techniques, resume building, and networking, enhancing their readiness to secure positions in cybersecurity. Furthermore, CMSP’s career fairs directly connected students with government employers, providing unique, low-competition opportunities tailored to their skills. Financial support from the program, including scholarships and funding for certifications and conference travel, also alleviated financial burdens, allowing students to focus fully on their studies and professional growth.

CMSP graduates also spoke highly of the program’s impact on their knowledge of cybersecurity, expanded professional relationships, and smoother transitions into government roles. Many participants noted that the program’s structure made it easier to complete collaborative senior projects, as they were able to team up with fellow CMSP students who brought a variety of experiences to the table.

In the broader context, the Drexel CMSP program has made substantial contributions to cybersecurity education. The Validation Theory Survey (VTS), conducted with both CMSP and general CCI students, showed that CMSP students experienced a high level of validation, both academically and interpersonally, in and out of the classroom. The program’s success offers a replicable model for other institutions aiming to support underrepresented students in cybersecurity, demonstrating how comprehensive mentorship, professional development, and hands-on experiences can cultivate a diverse and highly skilled workforce.

In sum, Drexel’s CyberCorps program has not only prepared students for impactful careers in government cybersecurity but has also demonstrated the effectiveness of targeted support systems in diversifying the field. The program has produced graduates ready to meet the nation’s cybersecurity needs, with a robust foundation of skills, experiences, and networks to thrive in this critical industry.
